title: A Sacrifice Remembered
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock lived a solitary life at the edge of the village, known for his gnarled hands and even gnarlier disposition. He’d retreated into himself after a tragedy years ago, rarely speaking and offering no help to anyone. The villagers tolerated him, but kept their distance.

One particularly harsh winter, a devastating blight struck the village's crops. Panic set in as food stores dwindled. The elders convened, desperately seeking a solution. They remembered an old legend – a hidden grove of hardy, blight-resistant fruit trees, located high on the treacherous slopes of the Dragon's Peak. But reaching them required scaling the icy cliffs and braving fierce winds – a perilous journey.

No one volunteered. The risk was too great. Fear gripped their hearts. Then, Old Man Hemlock, leaning heavily on his cane, stepped forward. Silence fell. “I know the way,” he rasped, his voice rusty from disuse. “I used to hunt on those slopes. I will go.”

The villagers were stunned. Why would he, a man who seemed to care for no one, risk his life for them? He offered no explanation, only a steely gaze that belied his frail appearance. He gathered his meager supplies and, with the blessings (and silent disbelief) of the village, began his ascent.

Days turned into agonizing nights. The villagers watched from below, praying for his safety. Finally, they saw him descending, laden with branches heavy with fruit. He collapsed at the village entrance, exhausted but triumphant. The village was saved.

Old Man Hemlock had risked everything, offering his knowledge, his strength, and potentially his life, to save a village that had largely ignored him. His act of selfless sacrifice transformed him in their eyes – and perhaps, even in his own.

This Lenten season (a coincidence of timing, not a requirement of reflection), consider the sacrifices that are asked of us, large and small. Are we willing to offer our time, our resources, our comfort, even our pride, for the sake of others? True sacrifice isn't about grand gestures; it's about the willingness to lay down our own needs for the benefit of others, reflecting the ultimate sacrifice made for us.
image_description: A snow-covered mountain path with a lone, weathered tree clinging to the side, laden with bright red fruit.
insights: Hemlock's journey mirrors the self-sacrificing love exemplified by Jesus Christ. Philippians 2:3-4 instructs, 'Do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit. Rather, in humility value others above yourselves, not looking to your own interests but each of you to the interests of the others.' This principle challenges us to move beyond our self-centered desires and prioritize the well-being of those around us. The act of sacrifice, whether small or large, reflects a heart that is aligned with God's love.
prayer: Lord, open my heart to see the needs of those around me. Grant me the courage to lay down my own desires and comfort for the sake of others. Help me to emulate the selfless love of Christ, offering my time, resources, and abilities to serve those in need. Remind me that true fulfillment comes not from what I gain, but from what I give away. Amen.
reflection: What are some practical ways you can demonstrate sacrificial love in your daily life? Is there someone in your sphere of influence who needs your help or support? Are you willing to step outside your comfort zone to meet their needs? What fears or hesitations prevent you from embracing a life of sacrifice?
